f2dVB1TcrwXMPqfdQFmfJA.text: I love the Japanese style cabbage pancake mix that is Okonomiyaki and that Abeno do very well. The novelty of having something cooked in front of you and that you break off to eat on your plate is definitely worth visiting and experiencing at least once for yourself. They have plenty of different variations that is best thought of a very savoury pancake with different sets of meats and vegetables that is both fairly quick and easy to cook and eat. The best bit is when they ask if you want additional toppings, add the okonomiyaki sauce, japanese mayonnaise, and then the bonito flakes that literally dance from the heat on the grill. It's both amusing and slightly disturbing if it's the first time you've seen it and you have no idea what it is. I've been in summer before and if it gets too hot, they can cook it away from the table though I think that takes some of the experience away. Abeno also do a variety of other traditional dishes (I've had their noodle omelette) and they do them all very well if you don't feel like okonomiyaki.

7nj_wcYqPV4mdsPlWu7cCg.text: A great place to try authentic Japanese savoury pancakes, cooked on the hotplate in your table! This is an exciting meal if you are out with your family or friends and tastes great. Abeno has a great selection of premium/organic ingredients more suited to the english market and their wide range of dishes are delicious and served fresh. Dinner is expensive, but it is one of the only places to enjoy this Japanese speciality and the staff and service is great.

hxNMWiO0IXY2Z_FNX9tzwQ.text: japanese restaurant which specialises in okonomiyaki, which is like the japanase version of a pancake. Wikipedia has a page on okonomiyaki. They also do other foods, like Om-soba, tempura onigiri and so on. The food is ok, not like a culinary experience but very nice. It is probably on the side of more contemporary easy going japanese food, i was surprised for example that the okonomiyaki comes with sauces like ketchup, mayonnaise or barbecue sauce (japanese version). It is very convenient if you are at the British Museum, and one million time better than the cafes inside the museum. Apparently a booking is recommended: turning up at 18.00 on a saturday, we were given a table only for 1.5 hrs because it was otherwise fully booked. It's quite cheap and the food is nice, so it is definitely recommended; if you are visiting london it's nearby a major attraction so if you are into japanese food or would like to try, don't miss it. you will be sitting at a table with a grill in the middle (which is part of the table, so be careful) and they will cook the okonomiyaki in front of you. Service is, it goes without saying, of the highest quality in the typical japanese style.

HYF7I5e8nUU7PE6FgdvXgQ.text: Okonomiyaki is AWESOME! Just as you'd get in Japan, with some twist of British. Service is what you'd expect from Japanese biz also, very helpful and fast. The only downside is the price - If they want to charge such high price, it should be twice as big. Location is really great for tourists heading to British Museum, it's just around the corner!

tlD9TI8xXOYMQqXv5-hd6A.text: Abeno is a cool restaurant as it veers away from the more typical Japanese fare of most other London restaurants, instead serving the Osakan speciality of okonomiyaki, a sort of omelette, filled with different ingredients of your choice. Once you've chosen the combination of meat, fish and vegetables you want from the menu, the food is cooked in front of you on a hotplate on the table which is a fun extra touch and also ensures it is served to you piping hot. It tastes really good too, meaning Abeno is a welcome addition to the London dining scene.

vJ3p0NBxKBUQGUa8ySzgrw.text: This Abeno is less cramped than the more heavily-reviewed Covent Garden one. It serves okonomiyaki, a sort of omelette-slash-pancake affair that you can have customised with lots of toppings. They are very tasty and watching them cook them on a hotplate built into your table is fun. Quite expensive for what they are, though. But certainly worth trying; and if you do, try them in this branch.

jEC94SV58C2-ZVTpzh504A.text: Have been eating here since it started. A unique but very European friendly authentic Japanese dining experience. And a rather above average wine list as well with several really first class bottles. Lots of inexpensive nibbles and a good choice of the 'cabbage pankake' (Okonomi Yaki) and Om-Sorba -Noodles  all of really high quality and very flavoursome.Everything is very fresh and of highest quality. A bit smoky with the cooking right in front of you so don't go in your finest though the after-smell dissapears in a day. Really nice Japanese staff, though remember that their english may require you to speak carefully. Be sure to schedule more than one visit so you get used to the menu. Once you have found how it works, then you will have the nice feeling of a place that calls you to dine there regularly. Recent visit confirms still on song. Look also to second, slightly different version in Great Newport St. Still going strong at latest visit!

ntQtfumXl9jH5B76GHGPFg.text: One of the best yelp finds since we arrived in London!  Normally you need a reservation for this location but since it was early on a Monday evening we were able to be seated with no problem.   An extremely warm and welcoming women (maybe owner) explained Okonomiyaki to us.  I've only heard of this but have never eaten it.  OH MY GOD Okonomiyaki!!!!  I had to make a formal apology to my stomach and soul for denying both for so long.  Okonomiyaki is a "pancake"  that consists of a batter made of flour and grated yam "nagaimo", shredded cabbage and egg. You can top your pancake with an endless list of choices.   It took us a while to decide what to order but finally selected.  I had prawns and squid and my husband chose the Kobe beef.  Both were cooked on a flat top in the middle of our table by our very experienced  waitress.  Each one was topped with two sauces, fish flake and dried seaweed flake.  It was one of the best things I've eaten in a very long time.  The service, food and overall experience was one of the food highlights of our London trip.

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. Tokyo Mix

fD6kSAxagQ326kEidDrJKg.text: Tucked away on Drury Lane is a little place called 'Abeno'. It may not be flash or two-hat dining, but the food is almost impossible to beat.Fresh ingredients (you have to try the salmon sashimi) pierce your nostrils as you sit down. The staff come and cook many of the meals on hot plates which are in the middle of your table, facilitating a very friendly back-and-forth between diners and waitstaff. I phoned up and was told by one of the staff that the place was fully booked but that he would call me back if anything came free. 20 minutes later he called back and got me a table.If you like Japanese food--or if you just like really well-cooked fresh food--you need to come here. Just a stone's throw from West End theatres, the perfect way to end a night.

mfTwqgXq7qfQPbXObCumZA.text: Okonomiaki was fabulous. Reminded me of my days in Yamanashi - ken. Also had mulled yuzu and ginger cocktail that was perfect.

6AJsmetemxYjk4jbux6T7A.text: This was a very interesting place to dine. I came here for a quick lunch with a friend. We are both studying abroad here in London and we were getting sick of eating sandwiches. So I just found this place and it was pretty good. We split a Tokyo and Osaka okonomiyaki and it was pretty delicious. The staff was very friendly and service was great. I do not recall what we ordered for dessert, but it was very unique (but small and overpriced). So I recommend you eat and then find your sweet tooth craving somewhere else.

irvIFRJnr70MiidRylyJ2g.text: Great food, reasonably priced, with friendly staff.  What more could you want?  Very happy to have found Abeno on Yelp.  The restaurant was just a block from the British Museum, yet reminiscent of Japan.  Highly recommend the okonmiyaki with all the toppings they suggest.  Sake by the boxful to ease things along, and HOME MADE green tea ice cream with red bean paste to finish.  Great meal at a great price.  Thanks Yelp!

M-j3NPBkfT0MvVkSD-QGPg.text: This is the restaurant that made me fall in love with okonomiyaki.  I came here with my husband on Valentine's Day once, and our server actually prepared our okonomiyaki in a little heart shape.  Little details that really made me love this place.It is pricey, but the quality speaks for the cost.  During lunch hours, the menu is a little cheaper, but it's a great place to have a date in the evening.

bOzoiN4Dtsb35E6TJHrAbQ.text: My friend Phoebe couldn't say enough good things about this place so of course we had to come check it out.  The service reminds me of a hibachi restaurant, big flat table grill, food prepared right in front of you while you sit mesmerized.Okonomiyaki is something I've obsessed over since my visit here and something I've not found since either.  Though thoughts of trying to recreate this omelet-like dish have crossed my mind I would even know how to begin.  How do you get the vegetables that crisp?  Even if I could figure out the ratio of eggs to other ingredients would I be able to recreate the pour?  Could I somehow manage to form it in to a perfect circle like our server/chef?  Would any mayonnaise ever compare?These are questions that remain to this day leaving me wishing there was somewhere, anywhere in New England that made okonomiyaki.  Abeno is a treat that will leave you wanting more and more.

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom

nrphQjLR1-7Tz8Ib1fFalA.text: Yum!  I came here for lunch today with a friend and it was fantastic.  I ordered an Osaka okonomiyaki and it was like one that I had in Japan - very authentic.  Great filling in the okonomiyaki and loved that the waiter did the cooking for us.  Service was in general very friendly and attentive, and I loved that they also served Calpico!  Also, typically I find that restaurants with grills at the table smell like grease - not a hint of it here.  Thumbs up, I will be back again.

yCGbMdwpQ5p-CiulL-va8g.text: This is a great restaurant to visit if you are looking for an 'experience' as well as a delicious meal. I was first taken here by a Japanese friend who rates it very highly, and have been going back (for the odd treat!) ever since! The first thing I noticed about this place was the very authentic decor, and the beautiful Japanese paper on the menus - different on each one - is a lovely touch. But best of all are the 'Okonomi' pancakes which are cooked for you on a hot-plate at your table, as these are delicious and quite unlike anything I've had elsewhere. The desserts are also well worth a try, and they vary according to season. Make sure you pick one with the delicious macha green tea powder for a memorable finish to your meal! This restaurant is quite pricey, but deservedly so. Good for special occasions.

QBIiwz-bCZN6EyS_IomhJQ.text: The food here has wonderful flavour and the service is excellent, with waiting staff who not only prepare the food at your table, but are knowledgeable and can answer questions about the dishes and accompaniments. The miso sauce is fantastic too! The two problems (that it drops a star for) is that food takes a long time to cook so not ideal if you're on a 1-hour lunch break, and the portions are not as big as they could be, leaving you feeling a little less than full.*Edit they now have a larger option so you can be full up

D3GyO3fTfPoB2pxrPWqvQw.text: mouthwatering! They were at the Jamie Oliver Big Feastival, so got to sample their food. I tried something that looked like a rice and egg pancake with chicken, and a range of sauces I wouldn't dare to normally try! Was delicious, will be stopping into the restaurant as soon as I get the chance!

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom

zsOI2M8w96XlkvfLKiFCxw.text: I enjoyed the food so much that I want to go back for a second today...!So the service wasn't the greatest but it wasn't the worst either... we still gave the waiter a tip!I found both the Kimchi squid and the garlic squid really salty! But it was really tender biting into it. Watching the waiter cooked in front of us, smelling the sizzling okonomiyaki made me more hungry! Just hoped they had a better vantilation because we literally smelt like the food when we stepped out... I think if I was still hungry, I would have taken a bite out of my own arm! LOL!Price wise was decent but a bit pricey... I still think it's worthy! Some of my friends think that this is too pricey just for an omlette.... it is not exactly an omlette and it tastes way better than an omlette, especially with the Japanese mayo and I think it's a bbq sauce on it. YUM! Thinking about it is making me drool!I think people should try it out. If you're extremely hungry, I wouldn't recommend you to go just because you'll be watching them cook in front of you and you can't eat until it's cooked.

DsAJRY2602TeX3XNYC7FlA.text: This place is way overrated.  And expensive!When I walked in, they hesitantly sat me down at 5:00pm, and warned me that they had a reservation for that table at 7:00pm.  Fine.  But if I hadn't sat down, would they have left the table empty for two hours?  Wouldn't you want that table generating business?In any case, I ordered the seafood okonomi-yaki, super delux.  Having had many great Korean seafood pancakes, I had high expectations for my 15 GBP pancake.  I was not impressed.  I didn't think this meal was of any higher quality than fried rice.  And I wouldn't pay 15 GBP for fried rice.

tvm6n-eBIWVTzFYge93h6g.text: Ah, okonomiyaki. It comes at a London price, but it's a delicious treat after a long day. I ordered the Tokyo mix (prawn, squid, & pork) which was very satisfying...especially with tons of Japanese mayo! Apparently you need to make reservations, but they let us in and rushed us throughout our meal so they could clear the table for the next group. That's alright, cause I was scarfing down the okonomiyaki anyway. It takes a little while to prepare, and at first I was wondering if I could make this myself at home, but my first bite assured me that nothing I made would taste this good.

U2-dobfNafbZ_dGps85Z9Q.text: I just got to know the word OKONOMIYAKI last night with a bunch of my food connoisseur friends. Abeno is such a wondrous place perfectly when you crave for savoy pancake, Japan style. Tthey make it right in front of you!!! It's a 2 min walk from British Museum so it's quite nice to have brunch over Abeno or post your museum visit for a quick bite. All staff members are so attentative, resourceful, and friendly. The FIVE STAR doesn't just come with the food :) Hope you can try it and share my feelings.

BWby9EHmcaWQ8nLegV5LNQ.text: what a fun place to eat at! the okonomiyaki is made right in front of you on a flat grill. you also get a small metal spatula to cut up the pancake after they've finished. interactive food. i like =) the wafu is delicious! they make the hotcake right in front of you and then bring out the green tea ice cream, red bean, and whipped cream on a small plate. yum!  wish there was one of these in the states.

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. Tokyo Mix

JGd5IMXtWihyu7QF-2h1zw.text: I'm going to do the same review for Abeno and Abeno Too, both of which are superb. They specialise in "Kansai-style of Okonomi-yaki" - which translates as "Japanese omlettes". The seating is unique - each little table has a heated panel in the centre of it upon which, after you've deliberated over the slightly bewildering array of options on offer - a member of staff will cook your omlette right under your nose! I must say, for this reason I would strongly advise that you think twice before going there on very hot days. However, with that caveat out of the way, Abeno is a great experience of a type of food you are unlikely to see in many places in London. While you're there try their sashimi beef and the "Geisha" cocktail. Verrrr niiice. hic

HP5TXQF7bL4TVipEWQRtzQ.text: Okonomiyaki power!  Forget that West End show, when you can go to Abeno to see some Japanese food wizardry!  Ok, so maybe it's not as exciting as Billy Elliot.  But this place is certainly entertaining, besides being yummy.  Okonomiyaki, the speciality here, is prepared fresh, from scratch right in front of you.  They bring the ingredients out in bowl, mix it in front of you, then cook it on the hot plate that's built into your table.  It may sound a bit gimmicky, but it feels authentic.  Here's a visual: abeno.co.uk/about_okonom…   And unlike sushi sometimes, I find this Japanese food totally filling, so it satisfies those with a healthy appetite.  Vegetarians will find lots of options too.  Tucked down a little street on the way to the British Musuem, this restaurant doesn't feel too loud or overwhelming.  Just make sure you make reservations, as this little spot books up fast.

kJGmXL7MzGJED0B-1Ooc3w.text: amazing Japanese omelette... I am not a big fan of omlettes or eggs and yes it sounds strange making a japanese Omlette but trust me its amazing!!  I always get the lunch special Okonomi- Yaki (Cheese & Spinach version)... this place is a real treat... they cook it in front of you and you get sauces to dip it in... YUM

F6iojwWytUBjzN20UbxRQg.text: Most definitely delicious. I had the Chef's special, followed the waiters suggestion , and finalized off with a exceptional frozen goodies dish .Classic cooking, dished in an unpretentious dining facility without a tremendous amount of fuss. Your meals definitely speaks for itself, and though vegetarians properly unearth their choice quite limited, it's a carnivore's bliss. Numerous business-types here on a week day lunch break, but the surroundings was still being fairly casual.Service was warm, attentive and thought to be without getting pushy or stuffy. Will quite go back try some of the a lot more adventurous bowls

--BIBuYU8QjaUcpyKtpI9g.text: Fact: Japan is my favorite travel destination. Fact: I love okonomiyakiFact: I love that I can get some made in London OK, so it's a little pricey for what it should be, but it's London and you saw what this city did to the burrito, right? You'll be central, you'll be paying for the table-entertainment of your server mixing, grilling, flipping and juuszing on your grill. I have to say, I really wish more places in London would embrace this style of table-cooking and service. It's a lot more social, ceremonial if you will, it makes eating a bit more interactive and the food becomes more of an occasion than just a function. The deluxe size was ok if you're not super hungry, you can top them with noodles or go larger. There's other sides and dishes of course but when in Abeno, do as the Osakans do. (order okonomiyaki).It's better than a couple of other ones I've had around town, give it a try!

UmEpnYAUk2v6xGHoQ85e2A.text: Went there just after our visit to British Museum. Not fully-authentic Japanese food but I believe it suits westerner's stomach. We ordered combo meal with Tokyo talk and London yaki. Overall they were very delicious but a bit expensive.

Wi8ZhfJr9Gvh5oF2_AmClw.text: Delicious Okonomi-Yaki, nice service, cozy environment. Highly recommended!I found it by chance, and I am extremely pleased with this place, I will surely come back here!

Vap1aUcZ5bS6nKkriE5e7A.text: This was the first time I had okonomiyaki. This was a very pleasant place to eat at and the wait staff was simply amazing. They cook the  food in front of you so you get first hand experience on the process of which it is made. It was a fun experience. I would definitely try to make reservations if you can, but if you don't be prepared to wait as it could take some time to get seated. We got lucky that when we got there, a table had just opened up and we just barely got there before a couple of other groups.

7qc_QOaquGI7LZvNky37Sg.text: My first intro to okonomiyaki...and yes, I am hooked. Nom.Abeno is a lovely restaurant, its small(ish) size gives it a home feeling. Okonomiyakis are cooked for you on your table, using that big heated surface in the middle. The staff will come with the different ingredients, mix them and cook in front of you. It's a great experience, and I'd recommend it if you like Japanese cuisine.There is a good number of choice on the menu, with different types of meat and whatnot. I went for an okonomiyaki with cheese and pork; which turned out to be particularly filling because of the cheese. But fear not, I am a small eater, so it is a good size portion. You can't really taste the cheese either, but you can tell it's there by the texture.Also, it's worth trying the Avocado & Tofu Gyoza. Not a common combination, but I found it delicious and surprising.

OBoz1ATQW4e5Lj0PjVPkQQ.text: We had okonomiyaki for the first time here, and it was delicious!.  Our server was super friendly, very informative, and just plain lovely.  We left seriously smelling like onions, but it was worthy it.

OqnnfEEscAykm1ZxsyB_xA.text: Abeno is the first place where I have ever tried Okonomyiaki. Good to know such stuff exists ;) Food was great, we have tried many different starters and small meals. Staff was very helpful, and enxplained us everything one might need in order to make good Okonomyiaki decisions ! It was also a warm treat after walking around humid and chilli London. The table where you sit, has large pan heating pan in the middle, so you will be always nice and warm there :)

RgoWs7_BsN_n0LIvjZz_SA.text: As an American Gringo who lived in Japan for a while (4 years), I've been on the hunt for a good okonmiyaki, as I travel the non-Japan world.  THIS IS IT!  The food is yummy, the service traditional Japanese - very polite!  If you have any gastronomical curiosity, you have to give these folks a shot. Highly recommended, and I'm tough to please.

FxMejBKk0xAhOhG7xnnLeQ.text: While in London, we went on an adventure to Abeno for lunch after I'd asked Alex S about okonomiyaki. He assured me this was the place to go, so off we went. Abeno is a smallish place, with nice Japanese decor (but not too over the top) and friendly staff. We were seated at a table for 4 but with the extra exciting addition of a grill right in the middle. We ordered some nigiri rice as well as our okonomiyaki, all opting to go for the London mix of bacon, cheese, pork and salmon. Weird combination, I know. The okonomiyaki is cooked right in front of you on the grill by the chef. It is really awesome to watch and adds a real element of fun to your meal. After checking the Abeno website, I see there are 7 steps to okonomiyaki enlightenment, which I will share with you: 1. The arrival. A trolley with the ingredients arrives for you to gaze at. 2. The mixing. The chef will mix together the batter right there are the table in a mesmerizing fashion. 3. The pouring. The batter is poured onto a very lightly oiled grill. 4. The shaping. It is pushed into a nice round shape. 5. The cooking. Well, that's kind of happening from stage 3 to be honest, but you get to hear the satisfying sizzle of the batter cooking away. 6. The flipping. Right before it's flipped, the bacon is added so that it is nicely cooked when it it flipped over. 7. The decoration. Once the okonomiyaki is done, it is decorated with Kewpie mayonnaise and okonomiyaki sauce (a little bit like a BBQ sauce). So, what was the taste verdict? Exceptional, it was absolutely perfect and I loved every bite of it. The strange combination of ingredients worked, and it was really a lovely lunch. We unfortunately had to dash off but the staff packed up our partly eaten okonomiyaki into boxes for us to finish later on that day. I'm glad to say even a few hours later it was still just as tasty. Nom!

JGAHomTcONcI3XvSdh68ZQ.text: I usually just stalk yelp to find good places in new areas but I have to write about Abeno. Just a short walk from my hotel and nearly empty in the late afternoon. Food was delicious but the service was even better. As a solo traveler it was great to be able to chat with the server about the history of the food, how it was made and the proper way to eat it. It was more of an experience than just a quick lunch which was greatly appreciated. Highly recommend!

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. Chocolate hotcake
Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. Spinach and cheese

k25bZuQCrLa3wHXpyQU-YA.text: Would have missed this place had I not been looking for it. Good service, told the lady we had to be gone in an hour and she made sure that we were accommodated. Terrific miso soup to start--perhaps the best of said soups I've had. I ordered the okonomiyaki Tokyo style (with porks, shrimps, and squids). Our server came out with a bowl of ingredients, whisked them all together, and poured it onto the stove-table in front of us. Took about 10 minutes to cook and then added a number of mysterious sauces and flakes (two of which seemed to be a Japanese mayonnaise and seaweed flakes. In the end, it was yummy and so I ate it. Good experience.

ZcmPE9f_z8Cv8Zp-D3m7tA.text: Food was decent, but the service took forever.  We stopped in on a Saturday afternoon.  It took an hour and fifteen for our meal, with most of the time spent waiting for our order to be taken, and for the food to come out.  There was only one waiter/chef for our section of the restaurant, and there definitely was no sense of urgency.  Again, the food was decent, but the quality and tastiness was not on par with the price.

n_uFo1vW1p1AqD9AR86XaQ.text: Good food. A bit small portion though.

BBCOw1NFmZLQHKF15dzO_g.text: Thank you, thank you, thank you Abeno. Thank you for fulfilling a couple of things for me. Firstly, I've been quite jaded with the Japanese places in Leamington. Wagamama is fantastic, don't get me wrong, but it's not TRUE Japanese food, is it? More so commercialized goodness for a bunch of white people. It's not that it's bad, it's just a bit blaaaah. Secondly, thank you for fulfilling a dream of mine and finally having okonomiyaki. And by God, it was delicious. The wait was horrendous for our party of four, but hey, we are newbies. I'll remember to make a reservation next time: PINKY SWEAR. Thank you kind hostess chick for making the googly-eyes with one friend and getting us a table. You're the bestest! The okonomiyaki was divine. You prepared it, fresh, in front of me, much to my delight. I almost spilled my ginger hot toddy, I was so giddy! Fresh eggs, mushrooms, veggies, quail eggs, and various spices/herbs/oils I can't even begin to remember. I do remember the Japanese mayo though. That was just WEIRD. No, Japan. Just ... no. Great experience. I added it to my "places that are bad ass and must frequent again" list. Because, you know, you rock. Although I am tempted to try the dim sum which is super close by as well .... decisions!!

_VMFYFcAHUM50XEVHpmIew.text: Just had my first ever Okonomi-yaki and I've got to say, I'm sold! I've been wanting to try it for ages but for some reason just never got around to getting to a Japanese restaurant that served it, but tonight was the night.The process is mesmerizing. The waiter comes to your table with a bowl full of the ingredients - egg, cabbage, 'tempura batter' and fillings, mixes them right up and pours it slowly on the grill built into your table, forming a nice little circle. As the first side fries up, he starts to cook the pork and lays it neatly on top of the batter mixture covering the surface. He places a lid on it and leaves it to cook. Then after a few flips here and there, he brings out an array of sauces and toppings to adorn the pancake in more deliciousness. We had the Inaka mix of pork, corn and Konnyaku, which is a mixture of yam and seaweed. Delicious! We also had the Om-soba with chicken, which is basically fried noodles wrapped in an omelette - a great choice, and then topped the meal off with a refreshing mango sorbet. I'll be back!

gXQn1b2Xyp-RMQuIYWoITQ.text: I found this great address on my Lonely Planet tourist guide and finally this year I celebrated my birthday to the Abeno restaurant.I had no regrets  okonomiyaki wasn't like in Paris (Aki Restaurant) the taste is very different and now, we know in Europe we could eat some really good okonomiyaki like in Japan.The staff and waiter were so kind and lovely. Okonomiyaki are cooked by your waiter on your hot table.On the Abeno menu you have soba, yakisoba, some tsukemono, gyoza, okonomiyaki, japanese desserts, good sake and some weird drinks.If you really love japanese foods made by real japanese cooker, this address is for you.Some plates are not available in Abeno Too.Enjoy!!

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom

kcmCuFYXKvf9dokfJJ_ZjQ.text: IIII don't knoww mann. I just don't knowww. I was stuck between giving Abeno a three and a four star rating becauuse... I just. didn't. like. the... okonomiyaki...YEAH I know, there. I said it. Everyone who wrote a review seems to think okonomiyaki is the best thing ever, but really I just thought it was a giant ball of stir fry. I mean, yes, in essence okonomiyaki is just that, right? They mix all of your ingredients in a bowl and fry it all in front of you. Lots of oil to grease up the grill as it doesn't all cook in one go; they cook some of the mix, then cover it, then fry it a few times more while adding a little bit more ingredients every time. I decided to forfeit an extra 4 pounds to add noodles too as I wasn't sure if it would be filling enough..It was definitely more than filling! But I think it was all the oil and it tasted like most of my stir fry asian food but put together more uniquely. Granted, I chose a pretty standard order with pretty standard Asian ingredients you'd find in stir fry. It was their special dish for the day which had some organic pork (emphasis on organic, my guess is that's why it was the special), quail egg, some onions, cabbage, carrots, dough, etc. The waitress recommended that I try an okonomiyaki with cheese and I played it safe and ordered the mediocre! I just thought there'd be too much Western fusion by getting a cheese dish, but I know better now. So, I'm not going to give the place 3 stars just cause I made a poor choice, my tip is to try something more unique and go for the crazy mixes. Other than my okonomiyaki choice though, I thought the service was quite lovely. The kind waitress explained to me exactly what she was doing as she made me my dish and I thought that was really nice of her. She also gave me good recommendations, if only I had listened :) I think I'll also ask if I can try frying the batter myself next time as it looks really fun to cook and I can portion my sizes better without it being a giant greasy pancake the size of my head.

Q4eDrwPRD6xIDUP9ldfKBA.text: Three of us went there. We were seated fairly quickly. The place is cosy and not too crowded. This the first time I have eaten okonomiyaki. I ordered the Abeno special. If you are in a rush forget it. The special is cooked by the chief at your table and takes time to put the tasty masterpiece together.  The staff is very friendly and the whole experience is top notch with one exception. One person in our group ordered yakisoba and it was presented to us almost cold. (The reason for the one star deduction.) the meal was a bit expensive but you get to see the chief create the okonomiyaki.

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom

nT3oVWhrFsrcqiEbSXB4zA.text: Osaka! Good.Ikanamabananasomething! Good.Service! Good.I ate about 15 pounds worth, and it was interesting to watch them cook the food on the teppanyaki, despite no onion volcano.

d7MOnOhow87m4CqhsiRUSg.text: We had a wonderful afternoon here and enjoyed everything we ate. The okonomiyaki was so damn good. We chose the Osaka. The service was pretty good. We also enjoyed the gyoza, tempura and onigiri.

Ch4Z6RSvleUf6btwfVlU-Q.text: Mmm I love okonomiyaki - it's fun watching your food get cooked in front of you but it did take quite a long time to finally be able to eat it. It was delicious, but the portion sizes are also a little small. Luckily we had ordered the delicious pork appetizer (Buta Shoga-Yaki)We got the Shinshu and the Tokyo mix okonomiyaki - both were good and I was surprised to find that cheese does work with okonomiyaki. Be sure to get extra mayo and okonomiyaki sauce; it's delicious! Yes I would come back but again most repeat that portion sizes are small and this place can get a little pricey.

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom

VcPgH9q0LJNVkDjI3EQcew.text: Perhaps I didn't know what to expect and that is why I wasn't all too impressed.  I was certainly impressed when I walked in and saw that all the tables had a grill and that they made the food at your table.  I was really looking forward to the experience.  We ordered the Cottage Okonomiaki which was good but not great.  We also ordered an additional dish which I cannot remember and for dessert we did the chocolate 'pancake'.  For the prices charged, the portions are small, very small. Service is excellent and the people are very friendly.  I'm not sure if I would come back though...

JblOFmmwgIM1lJu7YaJhdg.text: This restaurant is very closed to The British Museum so it's a big plus after hours of walking in the museum. The food was great! Seaweed salad is so delicious but very different than what I had in the states; okonomiyaki is very yum and authentic with plenty of choices. The service was great too. I'm giving it 4 stars is because the air circulation inside the restaurant is really bad. All the stinky greasy smell stuck on our clothes....

6qapEjy0Rl9wzaVyfDM2zA.text: Eh. Stopped by here because we thought we'd grab a quick snack after heading out from the British Museum. Boy were we wrong. We were told that it would be 10-20 minutes but nope. We waited there for 35 minutes until we got our ONE okonomiyaki. Now if it was a good okonomiyaki, maybe I'd give it some slack but really there was nothing special about it. They were frugal about the toppings, it was soggy and there were barely and pieces of pork belly in it. Okonomiyaki is one of the easiest things to make and somehow they've managed to make it average. Oh and they charged an outrageous amount for one tiny little piece - about the size of my hand.

ujTahz3JsDLLue4Rs_HB6g.text: Japanese BBQ at its finest.  Prices are reasonable - you can fill up on amazing food for £15 if you order properly.  Their okonomi-yaki is out of this world.  Pop the noodles on top for an extra £4.50 and order super deluxe size, and you'll be full for two days on just £15.50 if you order the pork version.Staff is very friendly and responsive, always smiling.  The ambiance is nice enough, and it's not so loud as there are only a handful of tables.  This one is preferable to the same shop over by Seven Sisters, as this one takes reservations.  Don't try same-night, however, as they're tough to get less than a day out.

gpDttXzDGXCOv0f03b0ZJA.text: Service was extremely slow. When they finally took the order they made us wait even longer before telling us they had NO chicken so they couldn't make the order of 3 members of our group. Sadly, we all had to go without eating.

QhOzQFHGR3QbZ7mIs7ynPA.text: Good soul food with excellent value for money. Cooking at the table really sets the mood!

7aopLJV0PsHQaLAYZdVzSQ.text: It's nice, but my expectations were a little higher. Ordered the tokyo mix and the omu-soba, the Tokyo mix was pretty standard, but I'm not sure if I liked the omu-soba since it had some hot bits and other bits cold. Hmm maybe it's supposed to be like that. Still, if you like okonomiyaki Abeno is probably a safe option.

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. Omu-soba
Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom

yugGynT1dpvXQARq26GsYA.text: Uh oooh... another new food love. I feel I need to start frequenting oxygen bars instead of restaurants... They would be so much better for the waistline. Okonomo-yaki.A kind of Japanese pancake. Of sorts. Made out batter, cabbage and onions as a base, with fillings of your choice added. I got a 'London special' (when in Rome, ye know!) with salmon, bacon, pork (mixed into the batter), and cheese. There's a hot plate in the middle of the table (I guess they get made by the same dude who makes the Korean BBQ tables!) and a staff member comes over and makes the pancakes right there in front of you. There's a bit of ceremony to it so it's a seriously fun way of eating lunch.You get a &*$%load of sauces then to go on top - chili, Japanese mayo, shredded seaweed etc. All artfully placed by your star waiter. To wash down all that savoury goodness, I got an apricot juice. An. Apricot. Juice. A juice. Made out of apricots! Ok not quite. I just wanted to get you excited. It was some type soda water with an apricot down at the bottom which had completely flavoured the drink. There may have been some sugar added too as it was pretty sweet, but goddamit, it was so refreshing I did not want it to end. The pancakes come in two sizes - delux and super delux. I was absolutely stuffed to the brim after the delux, so the super is probably for the hardcore amongst us. Or those who want to eat it again later on (which I so would!) As far as I'm aware, you need to make reservations for this one, although it was relatively quiet when I was there. So there you have it. Another five star review. Sure where would ye get it!

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. Yum yum yum apricot soooodddaaaaaaaaaaaaa

EDuronS2VNXhl6igQAux7w.text: I was spending my afternoon at the British Museum and needed lunch. I pulled up Yelp and found this place so I decided to try it out. I'm a little on the fence here. On one hand I like that they cook the okonomiyaki in front of you. It's certainly a plus if you're introducing people to okonomiyaki. I also thought the okonomiyaki itself was pretty good. However, okonomiyaki is street food in Japan. And £13 for a lunch special? I had to deduct a star for that. Especially because the okonomiyaki didn't exactly blow my mind. I even tried their London style okonomiyaki. I might be a little spoiled since I do get very good okonomiyaki for cheap back in NY but I was speaking with another friend who has lived in London and he is in agreement. So in conclusion I can only rate Abeno 3 stars.

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom

tbObAx0q538dQku5aWoSfg.text: Had the London okonomiyaki lunch special. While it's a little expensive at dinner, the lunch special is actually a pretty good deal at 13.95 for the okonomiyaki, miso soup, and side of the day. The ingredients were high quality and tasty. The food stays hot throughout your meal.

CtVH2LotMAV7uulUpfXoOQ.text: Came here yesterday afternoon for a late lunch. Lunch special was still available when I came in so I ordered the lunch combo with tokyo mix (pork, shrimp and squid) okonomiyaki with the daily side dish and miso soup. The side dish they had was gyoza with avocado and tofu filling. It's my first time having avocado gyoza and I'm not sure if I liked that taste... It seems a very odd combination to meNow for the main course of the meal: okonomiyaki. The server brings the mix to your table and makes it on the grill in front of you. It's pbbly a fun thing to watch for most ppl but I've seen it quite a few times before and made okonomiyaki on my own as well. The portion was smaller than expected but oh well it's london. The okonomiyaki tasted pretty good (okonomiyaki sauce and japanese mayo combined makes everything tastes good), quite authentic. I do wish there could be a little more shrimp in it.

6P3amo_HzfR9pkswAr1ACA.text: Fairly out of the ordinary. However, at first, I just didn't know if I meant "out of the ordinary" in a negative or complimentary sense. Yes, it is Japanese food. Yes, it it was tasty. So I suppose the criteria was met.If you do not know what they serve here, the best way I can describe the Okonomiyaki style dinner is like a custom-made omelette/pancake with any of the ingredients that you should wish to include.Best of all, it is cooked at your table! It certainly adds to the entertainment. However, if like me you are perpetually hungry, the tantalising smells and sites that emanate from in front of you while you are required to summon all of your internal patients to hold on for just a few minutes more for it to cook - agonising!Once it is cooked, they provide it with your option of sauce or not. I went with the sauce. It was tremendous.So all in all a great experience in this small but refined restaurant. Make sure you put aside the time to dine here, it is definitely not a grab and go type place. It was not too expensive either, fairly reasonable.If you want something different. While you are out and about in this part of town, go kit check it out. I'm sure you will not be disappointed.

-GP6ZTTUuEfoZ5o-oQBQ7g.text: Soo awesomeTaro chipsYaki sobaDrinks Pancake thing .. everythign so so soooo awesomethe drinks here were probably one of my favorites throughoutmy visit to london.this place is really Fun and they cook in front of you---hh

hUdjHDz-qytaRjvq9WV1Kg.text: Oh Abeno, Abeno... You are simply an amazing dining experience! Unique, unequivocally delicious, full of flavour, creative ingredients and so much fun to watch being made right at your table. If you have never had Okonomiyaki, basically, well, um... ok, it's kind of like a big Japanese omelet that is fried up on a grill at your table. You can choose from a load of different options - I had the London which has pork, bacon, cheese and salmon in it (I added corn 'cuz I loooove sweet corn!) Hubby had the Tokyo with squid and prawns in it. Then they bring your ingredients to the table in a bowl, crack and egg in it, whip it up and then start to fry it on the table... it takes about 15 minutes to cook, then when it is done, a sweet bbq(ish) sauce along with a Japanese mayo is swirled on, topped with seaweed powder and those fish flakes that come alive when sprinkled on anything hot. Viola! And the best part, you eat it right off the hot grill, so every bite to the very end it hot, crispy and as delicious as the first bit. I can't wait to go back again. Thanks so much Mr Alex S for taking us to such an amazing restaurant experience.

mCK13smccuIdmr-i6ZWLpw.text: You'd think that a place this close to the British Museum would just rest on its laurels, but that's not the case. They actually seem to be catering mostly to a local crowd. We got the asparagus and prawn gyoza, which had a nice fresh flavor, although a little steep at £6.50. We also got the Osaka okonomi yaki and the  Kimpira Gobou, both great.

xS-FtvuZAHra2d7Mq4wq0Q.text: Okonomiyaki. Full stop. I hadn't heard of the dish before stumbling into this hidden gem just a few steps from the British museum but worth giving it a try. The service was very good and the food was quality.

9le1BwQ7ZRsvF5A8uoK-zw.text: I love Abeno! This might just be my favourite place to go for a meal in London because I'm always so happy here. The restaurant is a cosy, warm place near the British Museum and the okonomiyaki is yummy. I have tried the tofu, the seafood and the chicken with asparagus which is my favorite, but they were all great Japanese pancakes. It is fun watching them make it at your table and it's a good place to take a visitor so they can experience something different in London. It's not haute cuisine, but it is yummy and a great place to go with a group of friends.

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. Super deluxe and super yummy
Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. Super deluxe shinsu mix is ginormous. And this is without the fried egg on top:)
Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. Abeno Special super deluxe sized. Biggest okonomiyaki I've seen here!

Ci0BxTWyJqWDNn_zZ_M5lw.text: Going to Abeno is kind of a treat for me...it's not something where I would go on a more frequent basis, but it's the restaurant of choice for when visitors are in town and you want to introduce them to multi-cultural London...or if you simply want to turn your dinner into a culinary experience!And eating at Abeno is definitely an experience: their core competency (so to speak) is okonomyiaki, which are Japanese-style pancakes. Those who have been to Japan will recognise that it's a very common street food there...but here in London it's kind of a real delicacy!Why is it such an experience? -Well, because of the way your food is being prepared...right in front of you. The waiter brings all the pancake ingredients to the table and then mixes them together and spreads them out on the table grill...and at that point you cannot stop but salivating excessively. Once the pancakes are done, they are being decorated with Japanese Mayonnaise and other treats such as tuna flakes and seaweed-sprinkles...yummy!A few tips: first, if you want to go on the weekend, make sure you have a reservation as they are very busy; second, this is not fast food, and the whole dinner might go well beyond the 2hrs mark; third, if you plan on going here before going clubbing or so - don't! Because you might not be the most-attractive smelling person once you leave the restaurant!Guten Appetit!

YG0JU7C3imrkWsVhsxJhCw.text: Yummmyyyy fried noodles, pancake and kimchi pork belly!! So good. Cozy. Recommend reservations. A little on the pricy side, but the food was very good!

n4D4mUPcHJuGmqT88MyMSQ.text: My current favorite spot in London. Amazing okonomiyaki that we can make on the table. Really nice staff who are Japanese. Feels like we are in Osaka.They have a new menu that includes many more vegetarian options. Definitely make a reservation as this place fills up fast!

sF1DjO29zFxQBvMBETNuMg.text: Omg..this place is horrible.. I never had such a bad okonomiyaki than here. First of all the staff who cooked front of us are untrained. They don't know how to cook.. and the food is burnt. In Japan you never squash okonomiyaki like here. It is so unprofessional...

iGWYPIIn6J7F68KMetkbeQ.text: I wish I could give it 4.5 stars. Service was great and they were so so so nice, food was awesome. Fun place to eat, but you will wind up smelling like cooking.

Lpmi6hX1eJq4-e2m2oPwFg.text: My friends and I stumbled upon this place while walking around and the food looked really good from outside. Honestly, I would say the food looked better than it tasted. The tofu okonomiyaki was alright, nothing really special about it. The service was really good. However this place just isn't something I would go out of my way to eat again.

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom

6X6wIVtyvdYBu5DKYGGTmg.text: Abeno's concept is okonomiyaki made in front of you. Not all that impressive but the food was really decent.My friend and I came mid-afternoon on a Saturday and the restaurant was pretty packed. Luckily we didn't have to wait. The menu features a variety of okonomiyaki that come in a deluxe size (recommended 1-2 people) and a super deluxe size (recommended 3-4 people). The base is all the same (batter, cabbage, spring onions, egg, etc) and you choose your toppings.We decided to share the agedashi tofu and the Tokyo Mix okonomiyaki, which comes with prawn, squid and pork as the toppings in the deluxe size. The agedashi tofu was on point but nothing mind blowing. The ingredients for the okonomiyaki were then brought to our table and cooked on the stove in front of us. The cooking wasn't that impressive and was a little awkward to be honest but the okonomiyaki tasted pretty good. The batter was flavorful and tasted pretty authentic. I thought the squid was going to be chewy but it turned out really tender and the prawns were big and tasted fresh too.Overall, I didn't care much for the cooking but the food was really decent. The waiters are really patient and helpful too. I'd come back if I was craving Okonomiyaki again.

oz6xyJlMuQuLqwX5lD0NSA.text: Amazing food. Been there once with a friend a few months back, it was hard to get in back then. Now it's even worse with closing of the Abeno Too. Amazing okonomiyaki, very good sashimi (first time trying it, but I've been told it's pretty good from a knowledgeable friend). They make the okonomiyaki next to you so no stress involved and you can see that they're honest. Service is also happy to give recommendations. Just be careful with the big option. I ate sashimi and 80% of the big okonomiyaki. Was heartbroken to leave some behind.Tried to go there for an occasion and couldn't book a table for two (on a Tuesday) with 3 days heads up. Book early.

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. Main course. Amazing. Prefer London mix but all are great
Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. Light and apparently very healthy dessert

JgjzuN03q7JhTl7uTwDbbw.text: My expectations weren't too high but it was actually a filling meal. Try to go for their lunch menu: the price is more reasonable

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. Tokyo okonomiyaki

iTEDranqTEiMmFfjUlW8_Q.text: If you want to explore the speciality of Japanese okomoni yaki, this is the place to try very close to the British museum.full of people and very popular. But it's not my thing, I mean the sauce is a little too sweet and the dough doesn't taste that good. Soft not crunchy. And It's just the essence of the food, no other taste, feeling like eating a dough directly. Looks like the Korean seafood pancake

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom

e48yV3wE4CE-hP9K7qDyMg.text: After a visit to the British Museum, we wanted a quick early dinner. A friend highly recommended Abeno. I always trust their culinary judgement and once again, they came through.Really liked:-- Tokyo Mix  Okonomiaki- Osaka Mix Okonomiaki- Mio Sake (which is sparkling sake - like champagne)- Chicken Om-SobaThe waiter was very helpful and described the 'pancakes'. He also was the one who cooked at the table for us. Overall, this was a great stop as the only place I can recall finding an okonomiaki place is in Japan. After a week of pub food, this is a welcome variety to the week.

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. Sparkling sake goes down well well
Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. Tokyo

2TcYqVT6cR5x6s48x0grqA.text: The food is basic (though healthy), the price is totally unrealistic for this sort of ingredients.

IQxLKTJHlK6lUTEzvTFiGg.text: I have been to other Japanese restaurants here in London and also in Germany before.I think this place is definitely a good place to go for a lunch when I compare it with previous ones. pros:tastehelpful staffprice for the mealcons:interior design is so averageprice for drinkstiny table space due to grill on the tablevery cold Air conditioning

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom

6o9Xpk9PuCpxlF5jME9W2w.text: It's hard to find good okonomiyaki other than in Japan, let alone in such a multitude of flavors. This place is delicious, has a large variety of dishes, and it doesn't get much fresher than this, because they make the okonomiyaki in front of you on the grill.Come with a party of 2-4 (but not more, because the tables are not very large). If you come for lunch, ask for the lunch menu. I was a little annoyed because I wasn't given one, and then charged the a la carte prices, when I had really ordered almost exactly what was on the (cheaper) lunch menu.Agedashi-dofu - Freshly deep-fried, without excess batter on the tofu, this was exactly how agedashi-dofu should be like. Decent portion size and easily sharable with 2-3 people. I think there were 4-5 pieces total.Tokyo Mix (Deluxe Size £12.95; Deluxe Super £14.95) - Pork, Squid & Prawn - I liked this combo of flavors - not too many things mixed together so that you couldn't enjoy the individual flavors. There was squid and prawn mixed into the batter, and cooked right in front of us at the table/on the grill, and then strips of bacon are layered on top. We also got the noodles on top because we're fatties like that, and it was so delicious, especially since it got crispy on the grill. The deluxe super is more than enough for 2 people and would probably feed 3 (but the 2 of us ate the whole thing)So many different combinations of flavors to choose from, and super authentic and fresh. I'd definitely come back here on another trip to London. If you like Japanese food, don't miss this place!

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. Okonomiyaki
Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. Cooking
Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. Making the okonomiyaki

0fV4J3BPya2mi7wBx0J4ZQ.text: Delightful food and service.  Extremely attentive staff prepare food on a hot-plate in the center of the table.  The food prep is not a gimmick but rather just ensures the high quality ingredients are cooked and served to perfection. I will definitely be going back.

KPgPfZ03m-TKKbASvQlldA.text: Yummy Okonomiyaki... I have had this more then once in Japan and I can tell you it's just as good here in London as it is in the land of the rising sun, The only difference being someone cooks it for you rather then you cook it your self as you do in Japan. As always the Japanese staff fall over them selfs to make you feel welcome and comfortable, Customer service is brilliant... The food is super fresh and very tasty and to top it off it's a very good experience and would go down well if on a first date or just taking the other half out for some browny points :-) Can be a littlePricey but eating in London generally is, don't let this place pass you by.

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. Yum
Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom

agFnKJ4SAfPdCXlmWbs3-Q.text: Prompt and kind service with delicious food. I had the iced barley tea, pork okonomiyaki and the seasonal mochi appetizer. Yum! I'd love to visit again before I leave.

XoKpCbfAgKG076rnbfGE0w.text: I like Abeno. Why? Because I love Okonomiyaki. I can't help feel amazement that hardly anyone else does this though. I have been to Japan and love this dish. So Savoury, sweet and tasty all at same time.Abeno does it well, right in front of your eyes, for a fair price too. It's a typical Japanese street food, casual dining dish but it's so good. I love food that is cooked fresh in front of you, a visual spectacle that is a lovely treat right before your eyes.

E3GYLLBk9GNR8F16wN7Yvw.text: We have a group of 9 people visited the on Saturday noon when they opened at 12pm, and they are famous for the signature one , which I cannot remember the name, but the waitress will always help you to make it perfect and all you have to do is eat hahahI actually ordered the Nola noodle which is fried noodle with pork and it comes fast. Some of my other friends also have fried rice and the taste was good

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. I ordered fried noodle with pork and my friends ordered the signature one here, but I cannot remember the name lol

CWQ6XOBjvU46ugkQY3Ckqw.text: okonomiaki is a typical japanese street food made with eggs and flour and some other ingredients of your choice like mushroom, shrimps, meatat this restaurant the dinner table is where they cook it! they cook everything in front of you and it is really nice also to see other food they cook (like dessert!)nothing posh, but very nice staff also and prices are quite low!

_y0YL5zdJcEKIBnUWFaUOA.text: The food and service here are great. They cook your okonomiyaki at the table which keeps it nice and warm for the whole meal. My friend is allergic to seafood but they had chicken yakisoba as well which was good. We were three people and we finished three bottles of sparkling wine. The place is quite small but you don't feel rushed. Would definitely recommend.

photos.caption: Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. Choccie is a chocolate chip pancake they make at your table. Great end to the meal.
Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. Kobe okonomiyaki
Photo of Abeno - London, United Kingdom. Squid okonomiyaki

TmJ_erk1WZt9BwDxyTPTeQ.text: I had never had okonmiyaki before, but I am glad I got to try it. It is a custom made omelette style pancake, and I had mine with tofu. They cook it on the hibachi in front of you and you can top it with certain sauces and bonito flakes if you wish. I really enjoyed it.I was also quite happy to see they had a sparkling sake which I enjoy but is very hard to find.Service was good and friendly, and the meal was reasonably priced (especially for London).A definite recommend if you are in London.
